    dlmextra - introduction

    Søren Højsgaard

    Wed Nov 25 13:25:18 2020

    dlmextra-intro.Rmd

    Introduction

    The dlmextra package (located at [https://github.com/hojsgaard/dlmextra]) enhances the dlm package (see [https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/dlm/index.html]) by providing extra functionality.

    library(dlmextra)
library(ggplot2)

    A small example: A dynamic regression model

    tt   <- seq(1, 6, by=1)
beta <- c(1, -.2)
dat  <- data.frame(tt=tt)
M    <- model.matrix(~ tt, data=dat)
dat$mu <- M %*% beta
set.seed(112021)
dat$y0 <- as.numeric(dat$mu) + rnorm(length(dat$mu), sd=.5)
    pt0 <- ggplot(data=dat) + geom_point(aes(tt, y0)) +
    geom_line(aes(x=tt, y=mu)) 
pt0

    Dynamic regression model in dlm 

    mm1 <- dlmModReg(M, addInt=FALSE, m0=beta, C0=diag(1,2), dW=rep(.1, 2))
mm1
    ## $FF
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    1
## 
## $V
##      [,1]
## [1,]    1
## 
## $GG
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    0
## [2,]    0    1
## 
## $W
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]  0.1  0.0
## [2,]  0.0  0.1
## 
## $JFF
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    2
## 
## $X
##   (Intercept) tt   
## 1     1           1
## 2     1           2
##   ...              
## 
## $m0
## [1]  1.0 -0.2
## 
## $C0
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    0
## [2,]    0    1

    The model is

    \[\begin{align} y_t &= F_t \theta_t + v_t; & v_t \sim N(0, V_t)\\ \theta_t &= G_t \theta_{t-1} + w_t; & w_t \sim N(0,W_t) \end{align}\]

    As the model is specified in dlmModReg the matrix \(F_t=[1, t]\) is really time dependent whereas \(G_t\), \(V_t\) and \(W_t\) are not (\(G_t=I\)). The \(F_t\) matrix is constructed on the fly on the basis of the model matrix:

    getFF(mm1, 1)
    ##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    1
    getFF(mm1, 2)
    ##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    2

    Imagine that we have only seen the first observations:

    nseen  <- 3
dat$y <- dat$y0
dat$y[-(1:nseen)] <- NA
dat$y
    ## [1] 1.557 0.262 0.416    NA    NA    NA

    We have

    dat
    ##   tt   mu     y0     y
## 1  1  0.8  1.557 1.557
## 2  2  0.6  0.262 0.262
## 3  3  0.4  0.416 0.416
## 4  4  0.2 -0.602    NA
## 5  5  0.0 -0.339    NA
## 6  6 -0.2 -0.242    NA
    M
    ##   (Intercept) tt
## 1           1  1
## 2           1  2
## 3           1  3
## 4           1  4
## 5           1  5
## 6           1  6
## attr(,"assign")
## [1] 0 1

    Filtering

    Filtering works because the time varying components can be constructed on the fly because the number of rows in the design matrix is at least the same as the length of \(y\) (including the missing values in \(y\)). Notice that there are two underlying engines for the filtering. Fortunately we get same results, but that is not always the case as we shall see below.

    fm1C <- dlmFilter(dat$y, mm1)          ## Filtering based on C code; default
fm1R <- dlmFilter(dat$y, mm1, debug=T) ## Filtering based on R code
fm1C$f
    ## [1]  0.8000  1.3803  0.2393  0.0835 -0.2023 -0.4881
    fm1R$f
    ## [1]  0.8000  1.3803  0.2393  0.0835 -0.2023 -0.4881
    ## FIXME: summary(fm1) would be nice

    Important issue: Filtering a shorter vector

    Consider filtering a shorter \(y\) vector:

    yshort <- dat$y[1:4]
fm2C <- dlmFilter(yshort, mm1)          ## Using C code
fm2R <- dlmFilter(yshort, mm1, debug=T) ## Using R code
fm2C$f
    ## [1] 0.800 1.320 0.823 0.389
    fm2R$f
    ## [1] 0.8000 1.3803 0.2393 0.0835

    When filtering is based on R code, we get results consistent with what happened when filtering the full \(y\) vector; with C code we get something else. This behaviour does not seem to be documented anywhere.

    Important issue: Filtering a longer vector

    A related issue is the following: Filtering a \(y\) vector longer than the number of rows in the design matrix should give an error in a non-constant model. (There is no information in the supplied model matrix for generating \(F_t\) for \(t>6\)). The R based engine correctly captures the problem; the C based engine does not. This behaviour does not seem to be documented anywhere.

    ylong <- c(dat$y, NA, NA)
fm3C <- try(dlmFilter(ylong, mm1))          ## Using C code
fm3R <- try(dlmFilter(ylong, mm1, debug=T)) ## Using R code
    ## Error in mod$X[i, mod$JFF[, 3]] : subscript out of bounds
    fm3C %>% lapply(head, 3)
    ## $y
## [1] 1.557 0.262 0.416
## 
## $mod
## $mod$m0
## [1]  1.0 -0.2
## 
## $mod$C0
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    0
## [2,]    0    1
## 
## $mod$FF
##      [,1] [,2]
## [1,]    1    1
## 
## 
## $m
##      [,1]   [,2]
## [1,] 1.00 -0.200
## [2,] 1.11  0.118
## [3,] 1.14 -0.144

## $U.C

## attr(,"condition")
## <simpleError in mod$X[i, mod$JFF[, 3]]: subscript out of bounds>

    Important issue: Recommendation

    Based on these findings, I recommend to stay on the safe side and always set debug=T. (Fast C code is nice; correct results are nicer.)

    ## FIXME: Should handle this in debug=T-issue in dlmextra

    Accessing a filtered object

    sel <- 1:6
getdlmf(fm1R, "m", select=sel)
    ##      [,1]    [,2]
## [1,] 1.00 -0.2000

    Filtering and forecasting

    The dlm::dlmForecast function does not work with non-constant models, i.e. models where \(F\), \(G\), \(V\) or \(W\) are vary with time. The problem is that if one of the components is time varying then this compenent needs to be constructed on the fly as explained above.

    try(dlm::dlmForecast(fm1R, nAhead=length(tt) - nseen))
    ## Error in dlm::dlmForecast(fm1R, nAhead = length(tt) - nseen) : 
##   dlmForecast only works with constant models

    However, forecasting is nothing but filtering with missing data. Hence, as long as the model matrix in the model object has “enough rows” for constructing time dependent quantities we are fine and can make the necessary computations as illustrated above:

    v  <- dlmXForecast(fm1R, nAhead=length(tt)-nseen, offset=nseen)
    ## dlmXForecast.dlmFiltered
## List of 3
##  $ m.start: num [1:2] 1.227 -0.286
##  $ nAhead : num 3
##  $ offset : num 3
    ci <- confint(v)
ci
    ##       fit   lwr  upr xrow
## 1  0.0835 -3.92 4.09    4
## 2 -0.2023 -6.02 5.62    5
## 3 -0.4881 -8.39 7.41    6

    A couple of nice plots

    Now we can plot with prediction intervals etc.

    ci$tt <- tt[ci$xrow]
pt1 <- pt0 +
    geom_vline(xintercept=tt[nseen], col="red")   + 
    geom_line(aes(x=tt, y=fit), data=ci, col="purple") +
    geom_errorbar(aes(x=tt, ymin=lwr, ymax=upr), data=ci)
pt1
